title: Gardenia brighamii
text:
Gardenia brighamii, commonly known as nānū, nau, or forest gardenia, is a species of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the <a href="Coffea">coffee</a> <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a>, <a href="Rubiaceae">Rubiaceae</a>, that is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>.
Description.
"Gardenia brighamii" is a small tree, reaching a height of . The glossy, dark green leaves are ovate, long and wide. The petals of the solitary, white flowers are fused at the base to form a tube in length and have six lobes.
Habitat and range.
Forest gardenia inhabits <a href="Hawaiian%20tropical%20dry%20forests">tropical dry forests</a> at elevations of . It previously could be found on all main islands, but today populations only exist on <a href="Maui">Maui</a>, <a href="Molokai">Molokai</a>, <a href="Oahu">Oahu</a>, and <a href="Lanai">Lānai</a>, and the <a href="Hawaii%20%28island%29">Big Island</a>.
Conservation.
The total population of "G. brighamii" is between 15 and 19 trees. There are only two plants in the wild on <a href="Oahu">Oahu</a> and one on the <a href="Hawaii%20%28island%29">Big Island</a>. Major threats to the survival of this species include loss of <a href="Hawaiian%20tropical%20dry%20forests">dry forest</a> habitat and the establishment of <a href="invasive%20species">invasive species</a>, such as fountain grass ("<a href="Pennisetum%20setaceum">Pennisetum setaceum</a>").
Uses.
<a href="Native%20Hawaiians">Native Hawaiians</a> made kua kuku (<a href="kapa">kapa</a> anvils) and pou (house posts) from the wood of nānū. A yellow kapa <a href="dye">dye</a> was derived from the fruit pulp. The white, fragrant <a href="flower">flower</a>s are used in <a href="Lei%20%28Hawaii%29">lei</a>. Today, it is grown as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a> on the islands.
